message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities suggests that the patient was struck by lightning, leading to ventricular fibrillation and no palpable pulses. Hypothermia, opioid overdose, and infective endocarditis do not typically produce these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fern-leaf pattern on the patient’s lower extremities suggests a lightning strike as the cause of his symptoms. Opioid overdose can cause respiratory depression, whereas hypothermia can slow down the heart rate, but both are not associated with the fern-leaf pattern. Infective endocarditis may cause cardiac symptoms but does not explain the fern-leaf pattern or the patient’s loss of pulses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on the lower extremities suggests a lightning strike, known as Lichtenberg figures. Additionally, ventricular fibrillation is a common complication of lightning strikes. Hypothermia can also cause ventricular fibrillation, but there are no other indications of hypothermia or cold exposure. Opioid overdose typically does not cause skin findings or ventricular fibrillation. Infective endocarditis can cause cardiac complications, but the presentation does not fit with the skin findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on the lower extremities are called Lichtenberg figures, which are a characteristic finding after a lightning strike. Ventricular fibrillation is also commonly seen in patients after a lightning strike. Hypothermia and opioid overdose are not associated with Lichtenberg figures or ventricular fibrillation. Infective endocarditis may cause cardiac complications, but it is not associated with the other findings in this patient.
